block.p: Around Town
Museums and Sites

HISTORIC RICHMOND TOWN Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmond Town. More than 25 buildings, from the late 17th to the 19th centuries, restored and furnished. Tavern Concert Series: tomorrow at 7:30 and 9 p.m., the Dirdy Birdies Jug Band; $15, members $12; requires reservation. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. (718) 351-1611. $5; $4 for 62+; $3.50 for students and 5 to 17; free for members and children under 5.

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. Tomorrow at 3 p.m., ''Speaking in Rhythms: Family Program,'' a look at the Garifuna culture of Central America, with a performance by the Speaking in Rhythms Percussion Ensemble. Sunday at 1 p.m., an Abraham Lincoln Brigade Reunion, with a musical program featuring Harry Belafonte, at the Teatro Heckscher, 1230 Fifth Avenue, between 104th and 105th Streets; a reception follows at the museum; $50, $40 for 65+, including lunch; reservations, (212) 674-5398. Through May 28, ''Robert Moses and the Modern City: Remaking the Metropolis,'' one of two exhibitions dedicated to Moses in the city; the other is at the Queens Museum of Art. Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (212) 534-1672, mcny.org. Suggested admission: $9; $5 for students and 62+; free for children under 12; $20 for families; free on Sundays, 10 a.m. to noon.

MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. Tonight at 7:30, a preview screening of the film ''Away from Her,'' directed by Sarah Polley, followed by a discussion with the filmmaker and a gallery reception ; $18, $12 for members; the film will open May 4. Also today, at 5 p.m., a screening of the 1965 film ''Darling,'' featuring Julie Christie, who is also featured in ''Away From Her''; the screening is included with museum admission. Wednesdays and Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, noon to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6:30 p.m.; and by appointment. (718) 784-0077, movingimage.us. Films and videos, unless noted, are free with admission: $10; ages 65+ and students, $7.50; 5 to 18, $5; free for members and children 4 and younger; free for everyone on Fridays from 4 to 8 p.m. (but admission is required for Friday-night screenings).

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 2 West 77th Street, Manhattan. Tomorrow at 9 a.m., a bird walk through the Ramble in Central Park; $15, $10 for students, educators and 65+, $8 for members. Through May 20: ''Audubon's Aviary: Natural Selection,'' a display of watercolors of 21 different bird species; and ''Carry Me Home: Dispatches From the Civil War,'' an exhibition of letters, photographs and other documents that provide firsthand accounts of the war from the front lines. Through May 28, ''A New Light on Tiffany: Clara Driscoll and the Tiffany Girls,'' an exhibition of lamps, windows, mosaics and other items designed by Driscoll, who worked in the Tiffany Studios. Through Sept. 3, ''New York Divided: Slavery and the Civil War,'' a display of historical documents, photographs, political cartoons and other items. Through July 1, ''Elegy in the Dust: Sept. 11 and the Chelsea Jeans Memorial,'' a glass-encased time capsule of items from that retail store at the time of the 9/11 attack, along with photographs from the society's collection that document events that day. Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; to 8 p.m. on Fridays. (212) 873-3400; nyhistory.org. $10; $7 for educators and 65+; $6 for students; free from 6 to 8 p.m. on Fridays, free at all times for children under 12.
Events
BOOK AND RECORDING SALE, St. Agnes branch of the New York Public Library, 444 Amsterdam Avenue, at 81st Street. Today and tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., and Sunday, noon to 5 p.m. (212) 799-6190.
CHELSEA VISITING NEIGHBORS STREET FESTIVAL, Eighth Avenue, between 14th and 23rd Streets. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
DOWNTOWN INDEPENDENT DEMOCRATS STREET FAIR, Maiden Lane, between South and Water Streets, Lower Manhattan. Today, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
EIGHTH ANNUAL WORLD TAI CHI-QIGONG DAY, Central Park, East Meadow, north of 97th Street. Tomorrow at 10 a.m., demonstrations of the ancient Chinese exercise as well as martial arts.
GRAND CENTRAL TERMINAL SPRING CRAFT FAIR, Vanderbilt Hall. Through May 12, daily, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.

LOWER MANHATTAN CULTURAL COUNCIL WORKSPACE: OPEN STUDIO WEEKEND, 120 Broadway, at Pine Street, eighth floor; and 200 Hudson Street, fourth floor. Tonight, 6 to 10 p.m., opening parties at both locations. Tomorrow and Sunday, studio visits, 1 to 6 p.m., as well as screenings, readings and a walking tour. Free, but reservations required: lmcc.net/openstudios.

NEW YORK UKE FEST, Theater for the New City, 155 First Avenue, at 10th Street, East Village. Today through Sunday, noon to 5 p.m. and 7 p.m. till closing, with performances of ukelele music by groups from around the world, as well as seminars and workshops. Schedule: nyukefest.com. $15 per concert today and tomorrow, $10 on Sunday; day passes, $90; full festival pass, $225.
19TH PRECINCT COMMUNITY COUNCIL FESTIVAL, 60th Street, between Fifth and Lexington Avenues. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
P.A.L. FESTIVAL, University Place, between Waverly Place and 14th Street, West Village. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Police Athletic League.
SIKH DAY FESTIVAL, Madison Avenue, between 23rd and 26th Streets. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
SPRING CRAFTS FESTIVAL, Broadway, from 66th Street to 72nd Street. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by Project Open, a social services agency for the elderly.
THIRD AVENUE MERCHANTS SPRING EXPO, from 23rd Street to 34th Street. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
Spoken Word

PEN WORLD VOICES: THE NEW YORK FESTIVAL OF WORLD LITERATURE continues through Sunday, with readings, workshops and conversations with noted writers and poets at various locations around the city. Schedule and ticket information: pen.org.

POEM IN YOUR POCKET DAY, Bryant Park, Avenue of the Americas at 42nd Street. Today, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., readings by poets of all ages; readers will receive a free poetry book. Sponsored by the Bryant Park Corporation, the Academy of American Poets, the Department of Cultural Affairs and other literary organizations; bryantpark.org. Free.

POETS HOUSE SHOWCASE, 72 Spring Street, SoHo. Through Monday, featuring more than 2,000 books, CDs and DVDs from more than 500 independent and commercial presses. Also lectures and readings. poetshouse.org.
Walking Tours
BERNIE'S NEW YORK Sunday at 2 p.m., ''Greenwich Village -- Forgotten Streets of the West Village,'' meeting on the southeast corner of West 13th Street and Seventh Avenue. (718) 655-1883; $10.

BIG ONION WALKING TOURS Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''Historic Harlem,'' meeting at the Schomburg Center, on the northwest corner of 135th Street and Lenox Avenue. (212) 439-1090; bigonion.com. $15; $12 for 63+; $10 for students and members of the New-York Historical Society.

BOWERY AND CANAL WALKING TOURS Sunday at 1 p.m., the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, meeting in front of Queen of All Saints Church, Vanderbilt and Lafayette Avenues. (917) 602-3543; $15, $12 for students.

BROOKLYN CENTER FOR THE URBAN ENVIRONMENT Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''Prospect Park: Vaux and Olmsted's Masterpiece,'' focuses on half of the park, which includes the ravine, meeting on the southeast corner of Prospect Park West and Union Street. $13; members, $10; 62+ and students, $8.

JOYCE GOLD HISTORY TOURS OF NEW YORK Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''Murray Hill: J. P. Morgan and Tales of the Gilded Age,'' meeting at the Kitano Hotel, Park Avenue at 38th Street. (212) 242-5762; $15, $12 for 65+.
I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN TOURS Tomorrow at 1 p.m., ''Literary Greenwich Village,'' meeting at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 12th Street, (732) 270-5559; $15.
IN DEPTH WALKING TOURS Sunday at 10 a.m., ''Revolution in the Streets'' tours 1775 New York, meeting at Fraunces Tavern, Pearl and Broad Streets, Lower Manhattan. (917) 607-9019; $20.

METRO TOUR SERVICE Today through Sunday at 2 p.m., Brooklyn Heights, Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, meeting in front of the Marriott Hotel, Adams and Tillary Streets, downtown Brooklyn. (718) 789-0430; $25.

MUNICIPAL ART SOCIETY Tomorrow at 11 a.m., ''Crown Heights North,'' includes mansions, row houses and religious and cultural institutions in this Brooklyn neighborhood, meeting on the northeast corner of Eastern Parkway and Kingston Avenue; $15, for members $12. Sunday, from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m., a bus and walking tour of Staten Island that includes stops at Snug Harbor, the Staten Island Botanical Garden and a Sept. 11 memorial, meeting at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street; $50, for members $40, including lunch; (212) 439-1049; mas.org.
NOSHWALKS Tomorrow at 2:30 p.m., a sampling of Brazilian, Greek and Tibetan fare in Astoria, Queens, meeting at El Sitio de Astoria, 35-55 31st Street, (212) 222-2243; $3.
OUTDOORS CLUB Sunday at 10:30 a.m., a 10-mile walk in the Bowne Park neighborhood of northern Queens, meeting in Queens in front of Old Navy, Main Street and Roosevelt Avenue. (718) 472-9620; $3.

SHOREWALKERS Tomorrow at 9 a.m. ''Bridges and Waterways of Central Park,'' from Central Park South to the Harlem Meer, meeting at the entrance to the Time Warner Atrium, Columbus Circle and 59th Street. (917) 912-9533; $3.
TIMELINE TOURING: 'A LIVING HISTORY TOUR OF THE LOWER EAST SIDE' Sunday at 1:15 p.m. $38; $32 for children. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 209-3370 or timelinetouring.com.
WALKABOUT NEW YORK Sunday at 1 p.m., the cultural and architectural history of Brooklyn Heights, meeting in front of the Brooklyn Heights Cinema, at Orange and Pineapple Streets. (347) 463-2864; $15.

WORLD'S FAIR ARCHITECTURE, tomorrow at 2 p.m., includes the Unisphere, the New York Hall of Science and the New York State Pavilion, meeting in Queens outside the gift shop of the tour's sponsor, the Queens Museum, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, off the entrance to the north parking lot at 111th Street. (718) 592-9700, Ext. 222; preddy@queensmuseum.org. Free, but reservations are required.
Recreation

ARTHRITIS WALK, Battery Park, Lower Manhattan. One- or 3.1-mile walk route, and activities. Sunday at 10 a.m.; registration begins at 9 a.m. Sponsored by the New York chapter of the Arthritis Foundation. Arthritis.org/events/arthritiswalk.

FIFTH ANNUAL RUN AS ONE, Central Park. Sunday at 8:30 a.m., a four-mile run beginning on the East Drive and 68th Street; a 1.7-mile health walk begins at 8:45 a.m. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club and JP Morgan Chase. (212) 860-4455; www.nyrrc.org. Advance registration: $30; $20 for members; $14 for 18 and younger and 62+. Race-day registration: $35; $25 for members; $15 for 18 and younger and 62+.

WALK AMERICA 2007, sponsored by the March of Dimes. A six-mile walk on Sunday, beginning at 9 a.m. at Lincoln Center; check-in, 8 a.m. Walkers should raise a minimum of $25 in pledges. (212) 353-8353.
